text: Bekka
hello my needle drops Anthony Fantino
here the most tiredest music nerd but
not too tired to review some fresh metal
vector outer isolation this is the
latest album from this Phoenix metal
outfit the last time we heard from them
is when they drop the album black future
in 2009 it was exactly two years ago
this month actually and that LP created
quite a stir in the metal community just
such an intense blend of thrash metal
and black metal too with all these
spacey themes working themselves into
the little lyrics and all of that of
course is backed up with loads of
technical ability and innovation
definitely not an easy album to follow
up at a prime example that sometimes
artists are more in competition with
their own material than they are with
other bands so I'm really happy to say
that this album comes with some very
noticeable changes but for the most part
vector has written a series of tunes in
their usual style without repeating
themselves all that much surprisingly if
anything this record just kind of
continues to define vector style as a
hyper melodic super dynamic
intergalactic space thrash band now one
of my few few issues of black futures
that it could have used more variety and
that definitely gets addressed on this
album of course they're just intense
riffs and and tempos on this record
sometimes the the drum fills and the
busy leads just kind of come together
and hit speeds that would make me wonder
if my record player were broken assuming
I was playing this on vinyl but you know
that's one of vectors calling cards to
begin with
what makes this LP sort of different to
me that it is the increase of slower and
more melodic passage
on here the softer and slower spots on
here definitely have more focus they
have more purpose they're just not
introducing things and allowing songs to
have kind of a clean exit the softer
spots are kind of starting to steal the
show for me like the really droney
atmospheric introduction to the title
track that was a nice fresh sound for
this band or the sudden loss and speed
on the track Tetris structural Minds
which man it's it's just so beautiful
it's like everything just goes
slow-motion after going the speed of
light for for almost an eternity and
it's like watching the Death Star blow
up for the first time kind of beautiful
destructive and poetic all at once that
moment is just really stunningly
beautiful to me along with others I love
the the clean glistening arpeggios for
me even the faster and more intense
moments on this LP air coming off a
little more melodic vectors always
managed to work leads into their songs
really well but I feel like they are
layering a bit more this time around
making things just really harmonious you
know these little mean guitar phrases
that pop up here and there the way that
vector is now stacking them on top of
each other it kind of reminds me of
listening to video game musics just
halfway into the title track on here I
kind of feel like I'm listening to the
theme song from Mega Man 2's air man
level and some of the sinister and
romantic court progressions on Venus
Project have kind of a Castlevania vibe
to them overall I just don't feel as
pummeled or punished by this album I've
got breathing room this time around and
for some reason I'm not really catching
the strong black metal influences and
sounds that I heard on black future
vectors always had much more going for
them than a blend of of different styles
they are unbelievably tight but also
showcase a lot of finesse as they
transition from one speed to another one
volume and sonic texture to the next and
on some of the tunes here they showcase
some extremely impressive syncope
which was one of the highlights for me
from that new liturgy record Aesthetica
now for anybody who is new to this band
I will kind of warn you
frontman David de Santo does have one of
the most unique voices I've heard in
metal bar none it's kind of like a black
metal wretch but there's a much higher
pitch to it in general and there's so
much more rasp going on there in the
throat the high-pitched banshee calls
that we're all over black feature are in
full throttle on this LP they really do
pop up more and also efforts are made to
change up vocal styles too with some
narrations some lower growls some clean
vocals here and there I was extremely
impressed and satisfied with this record
I wouldn't call this a disappointment
not by a long shot
I would say one of the major negatives
to this LP though is that there are some
moments on here that kind of sound a
little too much like black future for
their own good
that's difficult to do when you're still
mining for new songs from your old
material our isolation actually uses
tracks from the band's self-released
CD that came out before black Future 3
to be exact which isn't anything
completely new that since black Future
did the same and the remakes are great
those songs do finally get the
production quality they need to really
pack the punch they were intended to but
I was hoping this band's inherent
ambition would cause them to kind of
make a greater leap forward with this
record stylistically I guess still this
record and the previous one are enough
for me to to say to you that this band
in my opinion is the most standout group
in modern thrash metal sure obvious
comparisons can be made to past greats
like Voivod for example but what I love
so much about vector is that they sound
new they make thrash metal sound new to
me all over again and with all the the
science fiction themes the
musicianship and clear differences
between consistently good songs all of
those things add up to for me one of the
best metal releases of this year feeling
a strong 8 to a light 9 on this album
but what do you think of this record do
you love it do you hate it why and what
should I review next anthony Fantana
vector our isolator
you
